Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Degrading Offshore Permafrost and Arctic Hydrates as a Current and Potential Source of Methane on the Siberian Arctic Shelf
Award.AbstractNarration: The Arctic region contains a huge amount of organic carbon, referred to as the Arctic Carbon Hyper Pool, within the Arctic Ocean sedimentary basin. This area has the highest documented rates of coastal sedimentation with annual accumulation rates of about 10 million metric tons organic C per year, which approximately equals the amount of sediment accumulated over the entire pelagic zone of the World Ocean. Due to the specific features of sedimentation and lithogenesis in this area, much of this organic carbon survives decomposition, and is buried within seabed sediments. These sediments are frozen annually or seasonally, representing a substantial reservoir of potentially labile organic carbon. Global warming in the arctic region is predicted to be substantial, and possibly rapid, in next few decades. Upon the melting of permafrost, old stored carbon will be reintroduced into the modern carbon biogeochemical cycle, possibly acting as a strong source of methane to the overlying water and potentially the atmosphere. Additionally, extremely large amounts of more ancient (Pleistocene) methane are trapped as gas hydrates within and beneath the permafrost. This research aims to elucidate the present and future methane flux potential of sediments and permafrost in regions of the East Siberian Arctic Shelf. As a result of global warming, seafloor permafrost along the East Siberian Arctic Shelf may experience a pronounced change in thermal regime. Increased temperature may affect permafrost in several ways, ultimately leading to its degradation and enhanced CH4 release. An international, interdisciplinary research team will determine the distribution and stability of permafrost on the East Siberian Arctic Shelf and evaluate this area as a methane source to the arctic region. Cores from eleven locations will be obtained using dry drilling techniques. Rates of biological methane production and consumption (oxidation) will be quantified in permafrost and sediments at in situ and elevated temperatures. Natural abundance stable carbon and hydrogen isotope measurements will be used to quantify the age and source of methane collected from different sites and depths. These data will be used as input to numerical models, which will be developed to describe the thermodynamic and biogeochemical aspects of permafrost methane dynamics. Using field data and modeling, the current and future potential release of methane from offshore permafrost will be determined and a methane budget for the East Siberian Arctic Shelf will be constructed.

WHY TO FOCUS ON THE EAST SIBERIAN ARCTIC SHELF? 

 The East Siberian Arctic Shelf (ESAS) is a methane-rich area that encompasses more than 2 million square kilometers of seafloor in the Arctic Ocean – it is the broadest and shallowest shelf in the  World Ocean. ESAS is a part of the Arctic region, which preserves more than 80% of existing worldwide subsea permafrost (grounds remaining frozen for two or more years) (Fig.1a). Subsea permafrost started warming about 10-15 thousands years ago after it is inundated with seawater, which is much warmer than permafrost and keeps warming affected by modern global warming (Fig.1b). The ESAS is also part of the so-called “Arctic carbon super pool”, which means that more than 30% of the worldwide organic carbon (OC) is stored in the Arctic. Large fraction of this OC has been transformed in to methane and is preserved within and beneath permafrost (frozen grounds) as hydrates, which are the most vulnerable part of the Arctic carbon pool (Fig.1c). When subsea permafrost reaches the thaw point, hydrates convert into free gas, which releases to the water. As water in the ESAS is very shallow (mean depth is 53 m, Fig.1d), methane passes through the water column and escapes to the atmosphere, increasing greenhouse effect and, thus, accelerating warming of our planet. We suggest that release of only ~2% of the estimated ESAS methane potential into the atmosphere might double the modern burden of the atmospheric methane (~5Gt).

Thus, to accurately predict future methane releases, we must understand the size of the reservoir (the amount of methane that potentially could be released), as well the processes that have kept it trapped and those that control its release. In our project we aimed to address the most important questions: Are changing ESAS thermal conditions causing the permafrost to thaw? Is thawing subsea permafrost provides methane with migration paths? How much methane is currently releases?


FIELD WORK IN THE ESAS AND MAJOR FINDINGS

To address the question presented above, in April of 2011, March-April of 2012, and April 2013 we drilled the subsea permafrost in the Laptev Sea. The expedition transport caravan included two heavy caterpillars (T-150s), a drilling rig (URB-4T), two mobile houses on sledges, an all-terrain vehicle, and two cargo sledges, with a total weight exceeding 180 tons. The transport started from small Russian Arctic town Tiksi located on the coast of the Laptev Sea, Arctic Ocean (Fig. 2). Snapshots of winter field work in the
Laptev Sea are shown in Fig.3.

We found that in the ESAS near-shore zone the mean annual bottom water temperature has increased >0.5ºC during the last fourteen years (1999-2012); in summer this increase reaches >1ºC (Fig.4). As a result, increasing temperatures near the seabed impact the stability of subsea permafrost and the carbon pool buried in the ESAS. The temperature of the sediment core extracted from the borehole varied from -1.8°C to 0°C, which is much warmer than that of on-land permafrost and is about the thaw point (Fig. 5).  

Our results demonstrate that bottom water warming determines the distribution of open taliks (talik – thaw permafrost body) in the coastal ESAS area; this distribution correlates well with hot spot areas that exhibit highly elevated aqueous CH4 concentrations (Fig. 6).

Previous estimates performed for the ESAS suggested that the area was releasing 8 Tg or 8 million tons of methane into the atmosphere yearly (Shakhova et al., 2010ab).
